4C3F30AD95AC404D9E3E56A45D8851A6.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

98DE803273B94770B5B92AC6CE49ACDE.description:
Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.
a. Understand that the probability of a compound event is the fraction of outcomes in the sample space for which
the compound event occurs.

b. Represent sample spaces for compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams and other methods.
Identify the outcomes in the sample space which compose the event.

c. Design and use a simulation to generate frequencies for compound events.

9D9524B72DFC44A58981298B509C62DF.description:
Investigate chance processes
and develop, use, and
evaluate probability models.

6AA95C04C7A64A038D88A08E610A33B1.description:
Construct a two-way table summarizing data on two categorical variables collected from
the same subjects; identify possible association between the two variables.

71F57B2E72E04B9CBE48E01265F2FB51.description:
Analyze displays of bivariate data to develop or select appropriate claims about those
data.

367C973557CC4C05A79250C45684D176.description:
Understand that patterns of association can also be seen in bivariate categorical data by displaying frequencies
and relative frequencies in a two-way table. Construct and interpret a two-way table summarizing data on two
categorical variables collected from the same subjects. Use relative frequencies calculated for rows or columns to
describe possible association between the two variables.

6FA014A603DB43CDB7C4985CB16F6650.description: Interpret the slope and the y-intercept of a line in the context of a problem.

BABD415460F74747AEB7754156EA4DB5.description:
Use the equation of a linear model to solve problems in the context of bivariate measurement data, interpreting
the slope and intercept.

891FF204DD0B416C95B916F992A79EF1.description:
Distinguish between a linear and non-linear association when analyzing bivariate data on
a scatter plot

CC72360926324D5A8F6CA3F38AF86DDC.description:
Know that straight lines are widely used to model relationships between two quantitative variables. For scatter
plots that suggest a linear association, informally fit a straight line, and informally assess the model fit by judging
the closeness of the data points to the line.

1849E8090226465F8B73911CF7556DC5.description: using box plots and scatter plots, identify data points that appear to be outliers.

87AEA04628AF4723930446DA6097C64C.description:
Graph bivariate data using scatter plots and identify possible associations between the
variables.

02F53F266DEA44A7908ED5CD5C1592BC.description: Graph data using line graphs, histograms, or box plots.

99506D2A8ADF4DFC9F200496E29E9D88.description: Recognize a pattern of association using existing data.

643B2F1188764B618DE789183EB5CD69.description:
Construct and interpret scatter plots for bivariate measurement data to investigate and describe patterns such as
clustering, outliers, positive or negative association, linear association, and nonlinear association.

3D8327E16F264CF6BD54F2D3D971268C.description:
Investigate patterns of
association in bivariate data.

529E58BA97D34C56A971D1808EA6FAC5.description:
Apply the formula to find the volume of 3 dimensional shapes (i.e., cubes, spheres, and
cylinders).

5F4CB3A448FB4776B10F0F5AAC226DD7.description:
Understand and use formulas for volumes of cones, cylinders and spheres and use them to solve real-world
context and mathematical problems.

DA1CF8F5A4C041D58E9EE70DC38B3084.description:
Solve real-world and
mathematical problems
involving volume of
cylinders, cones, and
spheres.

04110F12F2DA436AA788D5F1A1C803A0.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

AAA1B0201FB04EE496D82C6F725BDAE9.description: Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to find the distance between two points in a coordinate system.

04F0907AFB5C4ADBAA1E1DDBC9F0ABF4.description: Find the missing side lengths of a two-dimensional right triangle (Pythagorean Theorem).

3728C61EB0B145159E924909A6535B23.description: Find the hypotenuse of a two-dimensional right triangle (Pythagorean Theorem).

18D7947F330940C1A2D41DE990B0BD6C.description: Find the missing side lengths of a two-dimensional right triangle (Pythagorean Theorem).

999342BDDAF84747A9DE14A53858651A.description: Find the hypotenuse of a two-dimensional right triangle (Pythagorean Theorem).

6478C12243524D75A736AEBC3F1A7F41.description: Apply the Pythagorean theorem to determine lengths/distances in real-world situations.

36537D810711416682BBBFFFB7DDA44A.description:
Apply the Pythagorean Theorem to determine unknown side lengths in right triangles in real-world context and
mathematical problems in two and three dimensions.

7FC3475CE8C54F97BB19B3B4D80E19BC.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

1FBE8EA9D6FF4C2395AD04A9540615CD.description: Understand the Pythagorean Theorem and its converse.

BDC856FB0F8C4845AFA4DA3350E29283.description:
Understand and apply the
Pythagorean Theorem.

5DD5B2A453B247849022D415C033FDA0.description: Use angle relationships to find the value of a missing angle.

FD4C02B6645E493C876E8AC97CE14538.description:
Use informal arguments to establish facts about the angle sum and exterior angle of triangles, about the angles
created when parallel lines are cut by a transversal, and the angle-angle criterion for similarity of triangles. For
example, arrange three copies of the same triangle so that the sum of the three angles appears to form a line, and
give an argument in terms of transversals why this is so.

8793B5CFEDF249C494428548E1598541.description: Compare area and volume of similar figures.

719266705A464811AEA6F4C72930E332.description:
Describe the changes in surface area, area, and volume when the figure is changed in some
(e.g., scale drawings).

F70310CDDC7D49E6978E2E6C9DE06250.description:
Understand that a two-dimensional figure is similar to another if, and only if, one can be obtained from the other
by a sequence of rotations, reflections, translations, and dilations; given two similar two-dimensional figures,
describe a sequence that demonstrates similarity.

075EEC85BFF04C449A9C6DC5CEF85E15.description: Identify a rotation, reflection, or translation of a plane figure when given coordinates.

AD51636DF412405699356E7065A73CC8.description:
Describe the effect of dilations, translations, rotations, and reflections on two-dimensional figures using
coordinates.

4008FB8B358A40E5B4833CF977EFF5DD.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

7A908B645601465695E47CB772FE1B5A.description:
Understand that a two-dimensional figure is congruent to another if one can be obtained from the other by a
sequence of rotations, reflections, and translations; given two congruent figures, describe a sequence that
demonstrates congruence.

87CF90DFE3B34E239CCC7B09C21CE2F8.description:
Use the reflections, rotations, or translations in the coordinate plane to solve problems with
right angles.

25AFF420E889471993BBC62E6B8D7947.description: Recognize a rotation, reflection, or translation of a figure.

D5CCA09AFE1C43D395BBE9CDDD0EE26D.description:
Verify experimentally the properties of rotations, reflections, and translations. Properties include: lines are taken
to lines, line segments are taken to line segments of the same length, angles are taken to angles of the same
measure, parallel lines are taken to parallel lines.

2EBFBFBAEAE443C5AE5450A4EA59853D.description:
Analyze provided information (e.g., a graph) to describe the relationship between two
quantities.

A45548DF47134FCEADB4948C0213A46D.description:
describe or select the relationship between the two quantities given a line graph of a
situation.

792C850756904D2BA88809F98CF19800.description: Given a graph of a situation, generate a description of the situation.

5600B0B8C7DF4386BBA66B39D0650EBA.description:
Given a verbal description of a situation, create or identify a graph to model the
situation.

58122C16BF79454D9A2F3E6B5463E903.description: Given two graphs, describe the function as linear and not linear.

822B28F73F9B4649AC833F6C26FA5C4D.description:
Describe qualitatively the functional relationship between two quantities by analyzing a graph (e.g., where the
function is increasing or decreasing, linear or nonlinear). Sketch a graph that exhibits the qualitative features of a
function that has been described verbally.

DD0E6097783243DFB52DAB3015D15455.description: Identify the rate of change (slope) and initial value (y-intercept) from graphs.

662ADDFD77BE4679BF20E089CC0E389A.description:
Given a description of a situation, generate a function to model a linear relationship between two quantities.
Determine the rate of change and initial value of the function from a description of a relationship or from two (x, y) values, including reading these from a table or a graph. Track how the values of the two quantities change
together. Interpret the rate of change and initial value of a linear function in terms of the situation it models, its
graph, or its table of values.

BC296EB32F984981B0AAE6BC7EF8CC8F.description:
Use functions to model relationships between
quantities.

B69BDD8757254FE0973B70DB9D47AE60.description: Given two graphs, describe the function as linear and not linear.

D871B047A82A4D74861E2A370ED8168D.description:
Interpret the equation y = mx + b as defining a linear function whose graph is a straight line; give examples of
functions that are not linear. For example, the function A = s2 giving the area of a square as a function of its side
length in not linear because its graph contains the points (1,1), (2,4), and (3,9) which are not on a straight line.

54DE232670C14D7288A43DB6ACE04354.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

51413845D8FE406AB73CADE64D459BFE.description:
Compare properties of two functions each represented in a different way (algebraically, graphically, numerically
in tables, or by verbal descriptions). For example, given a linear function represented by a table of values and a
linear function represented by an algebraic expression, determine which function has the greater rate of change.

DA0D223C2599457BB4A216AF4174FEDC.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

72A269062FC74D0599BA2A787C81E9AC.description:
Understand that a function is a rule that assigns to each input exactly one output. The graph of a function is the
set of ordered pairs consisting of an input and the corresponding output. (Function notation is not required in
Grade 8.)

C516DDD5CD3E405EBBA068C451CB2A2B.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

D6E624A602AC4F7ABE121E6D7ED99C8F.description:
Analyze and solve pairs of simultaneous linear equations.
a. Understand that solutions to a system of two linear equations in two variables correspond to points of
intersection of their graphs, because points of intersection satisfy both equations simultaneously.
b. Solve systems of two linear equations in two variables algebraically, and estimate solutions by graphing
the equations including cases of no solution and infinite number of solutions. Solve simple cases by
inspection.
c. Solve mathematical problems and problems in real-world context leading to two linear equations in two
variables.

F0C51E7482374173A5B2064047B0258C.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

4B2D92D9F44B444CB5E1CBBD62D2C8C4.description:
Fluently solve linear equations and inequalities in one variable.
a. Give examples of linear equations in one variable with one solution, infinitely many solutions, or no
solution. Show which of these possibilities is the case by successively transforming the given equation
into simpler forms, until an equivalent equation of the form x = a, a = a, or a = b results (where a and b
are different numbers). b. Solve linear equations and inequalities with rational number coefficients, including solutions that require
expanding expressions using the distributive property and collecting like terms.

4F08D77D7F8B4C668D568FB92A43DB15.description:
Analyze and solve linear
equations, inequalities, and
pairs of simultaneous linear
equations.

EDCC10A711C045DE9C93B5D52B3457C6.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

CE4DFC177DA64780B397B5A14DD41B46.description:
Use similar triangles to explain why the slope m is the same between any two distinct points on a non-vertical line
in the coordinate plane. Derive the equation y = mx for a line through the origin and the equation y = mx + b for a
line intercepting the vertical axis at (0, b).

29CE1CD06055467D9D6515F6359BCA5A.description: Represent proportional relationships on a line graph.

D8C8E757A4EF426588F8FAB0A43A7970.description:
Graph proportional relationships interpreting the unit rate as the slope of the graph. Compare two different
proportional relationships represented in different ways. For example, compare a distance-time graph to a distance-time equation to determine which of two moving objects has greater speed.

F5252A498D894929AF178D512454082D.description:
Understand the connections between proportional
relationships, lines, and
linear equations.

F79FDC57DF0448B986A7F383499D344D.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

43C2EC68B7BF4F3F9D932D2DEEF50195.description:
Perform operations with numbers expressed in scientific notation including problems where both decimal and
scientific notation are used. Use scientific notation and choose units of appropriate size for measurements of very
large or very small quantities.

180A067AF58C41E2AF88855B58101BB5.description: Convert a number expressed in scientific notation up to 10,000.

135F843605A3401EB1C59B8FE8CF67B5.description:
Use numbers expressed in the form of a single digit times an integer power of 10 to estimate very large or very
small quantities, and express how many times larger or smaller one is than the other.

FA25A3D97C6D41998F32EDD0018DB940.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

5EE8CBC8A11E41D6B87E99CC9286F75C.description:
Use square root and cube root symbols to represent solutions to equations of the form x2 = p and x3
= p, where p
is a positive rational number. Know that √2 is irrational.
a. Evaluate square roots of perfect squares less than or equal to 225.
b. Evaluate cube roots of perfect cubes less than or equal to 1000.

8F83E2BF30794241AADE263208095193.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

08708B1E86C34B96AB224432B296DCF2.description: Understand and apply the properties of integer exponents to generate equivalent numerical expressions.

D0797714603949E8B322D12F8B02B1C2.description:
Work with radicals and
integer exponents.

60B1C4E9CAF4487CBF25BCBDDE49DA2E.description: No CCC developed for this standard.

E844BD2983D84D7AB65510FC886A2211.description:
Understand that given any two distinct rational numbers, a < b, there exist a rational number c and an irrational
number d such that a < c < b and a < d < b. Given any two distinct irrational numbers, a < b, there exist a rational
number c and an irrational number d such that a < c < b and a < d < b.

42210090F15045418C71E36C3C4644A9.description: Use approximations of irrational numbers to locate them on a number line.

E1AF73CE5B87417D81A023A37CC82062.description: Round irrational numbers to the hundredths place.

0C1F51A26684426EB0A793FC4C100363.description: Identify π as an irrational number.

7738B4143FAF4539964ABE0AAF6A04B0.description:
Use rational approximations of irrational numbers to compare the size of irrational numbers. Locate them
approximately on a number line diagram, and estimate their values.

C416380B50C14A3CA6E6182DDF27DFCF.description:
Know that numbers that are not rational are called irrational. Understand informally that every number has a
decimal expansion. Know that numbers whose decimal expansions do not terminate in zeros or in a repeating
sequence of fixed digits are called irrational.
No CCC developed for this standard.

70347F0EF9884574947FA58787CEB1D2.description:
Understand that there are
irrational numbers, and
approximate them using
rational numbers.
